text: In a agile product expansion in banking where the project has high uncertainty and procurement options vary, what should the project manager do to use iterative and incremental practices across the life cycle?

options.label: plan to deliver value in increments with regular feedback
hold all value until final delivery
avoid feedback to stay on the original plan
lock scope and ignore learning

explanation: Option a is correct because increments accelerate learning and value. Option b is incorrect because late delivery increases risk and delays value. Option c is incorrect because lack of feedback prevents adaptation. Option d is incorrect because iteration relies on learning and adjustment.

text: Given a outsourced infrastructure refresh in aviation where the project has high uncertainty and procurement options vary, which action best supports use iterative and incremental practices across the life cycle?

options.label: skip retrospectives to save time
timebox work and reviews to enable adaptation
treat iterations as mini waterfalls with no change
hold all value until final delivery

explanation: Option b is correct because timeboxes create rhythm and control. Option a is incorrect because skipping improvement keeps issues alive. Option c is incorrect because iterations should enable change. Option d is incorrect because late delivery increases risk and delays value.

text: While facing a incremental infrastructure refresh in pharma where stakeholder groups have competing goals and executives demand a clear approach, what is the most effective next step to use iterative and incremental practices across the life cycle?

options.label: avoid feedback to stay on the original plan
lock scope and ignore learning
reprioritize backlog or scope based on feedback
skip retrospectives to save time

explanation: Option c is correct because adaptation is central to iterative work. Option a is incorrect because lack of feedback prevents adaptation. Option b is incorrect because iteration relies on learning and adjustment. Option d is incorrect because skipping improvement keeps issues alive.

text: For a predictive product expansion in government where funding is gated and procurement options vary, what should the project manager do first to use iterative and incremental practices across the life cycle?

hold all value until final delivery
avoid feedback to stay on the original plan
run retrospectives to improve each cycle

explanation: Option d is correct because continuous improvement strengthens delivery. Option a is incorrect because iterations should enable change. Option b is incorrect because late delivery increases risk and delays value. Option c is incorrect because lack of feedback prevents adaptation.
